headline: GOP lawmaker wants to cut Ohio gasoline tax, end extra fees on hybrid, electric vehicles
author: Mary Jane Sanese
sentences:
Gas prices: 'The weeks ahead could be rather ugly': Gas prices are continuing to climb in Ohio
Also, Ohio's gas tax revenues are falling below projections because people are driving fewer miles during the pandemic.

Republican state Sen. Steve Huffman of Tipp City is sponsoring legislation to reduce the state motor fuel tax to 28-cents a gallon, down from 47-cents a gallon for diesel fuel and 38.5-cents for gasoline.

ODOT: Gas tax cut would cost $4 billion in revenue
If the gas tax cut goes through, Ohio would lose $4 billion over the next five years, according to the state Department of Transportation.
According to AAA, the average price of gas in Ohio has consistently risen in the last year, climbing more than $1 for diesel and nearly 70 cents for regular gas.
Mike DeWine, who pushed through higher gas taxes in 2019, has said rolling back the tax and fees would leave Ohio short of what's needed for road projects.
Huffman said this bill aims to help Ohioans keep some of their money since Ohio is set to receive $11.3 billion from the federal government.
According to the American Petroleum Institute, Ohio ranks 14th in the country for highest regular gasoline tax rates, and ninth for diesel.
"A gas tax is a tax on the poor," Huffman said, "It's tough to spend an extra 10 dollars a week on gas if you have a very limited budget."
Ohioans may pay less for gas and no longer be required to pay extra fees for hybrid and electric vehicles if a proposed bill becomes law.
Senate Bill 277 would also eliminate special registration fees paid by owners of hybrid and electric vehicles for the next five years.
State gas taxes, along with federal fuel taxes, are used to pay for road and bridge maintenance, repair and construction.
In 2020 and 2021 combined, gas tax revenues fell $464 million below expectations, according to state officials.

DeWine opposed to gas tax cut, says money needed to repair Ohio roads, bridges
The bill faces an uphill fight.
The 123,000 hybrids and 31,000 electric vehicle owners still use the roads but pay less or no gas taxes.
The DeWine administration is reviewing Huffman's bill, which had its first hearing last week.
The federal infrastructure fund would offset some but not all of those losses.
The special fee is $100 for hybrids and $200 for electric vehicles.
